attributes.title: EthicsApproval
attributes.description: Materials as submitted for ethics approval and ethics approval reference.

q1.value: The potential link between exculpation and stigmatization in Tourette Syndrome: a vignette study

q3.value:
Please refer to the protocol contained in materials.

Over-all research questions addressed:

Baseline study: Does viewing Tourettic behavior as neurological lead to both exculpation ​and​ social exclusion?

Disclosure study: Does epigenetic reframing of Tourettic behavior allow to find a better optimum between these components of stigma?

q4.value:
For detailed predictions please refer to the protocol contained in materials.

Baseline study: viewing Tourettic behavior as more neurological leads both to less attribution of blame and more social distance/isolation.

Disclosure study: epigenetic reframing in neurological condition leads to less social distance & social isolation whilst blame remains constant; epigenetic reframing in psychological condition leads to less blame whilst social distance & social isolation remain constant.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: The study is an on-line Qualtrics survey with fully anonymized participation. It will be rolled out via the Prolific service towards adult native English speakers in the age range 18-35 (in order to keep familiarity with classroom settings).

question.value:
Mixed design (for details, please refer to protocol document in materials):

For initial step: Spearman correlation between ‘Perceived Etiology’ (Biology-Psychology) and ‘Attribution of Blame’ (Likert 1/No-5/Yes): required sample size 115.

For neurological vs psychological condition: Mann-Whitney U tests on variables:

-​ ​Attribution of blame (1-5 Likert)
-​ ​Social Distance Scale (scale)
-​ ​Social isolation Question (1-5 Likert)
-​ ​Independent variable: group Bio or Psycho
Required sample size 92 in each group so 184 in total.

q9.value: Randomization between psychological and neurological conditions will be done via Qualtrics randomizer (see survey flow).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The Prolific service will be used to recruit participants & Quatrics service will be used to collect data. 

Power estimation indicates the need for 184 participants to cover the hypotheses. We decided to use 220 participants to take into account non-consent and partial responses (and to cover a possible exclusion of people diagnosed with Tourette or another diagnosis of mental 'disorder' or people directly acquainted with them given previous research shows their responses will be significantly different from those in the general public - see demographics part of survey). We also decided to restrict the age range from 18-35 to keep familiarity with classroom settings.

q15.value: We will distribute to a fixed group of 220 participants. When non-consent, partial or exclusion (see above) are unexpectedly high we will redistribute to more participants until we reach the power analysis requirement.

question.value: See protocol document in materials.
See protocol document in materials.
See protocol document in materials.
We will use the test implied by the power analysis as recorded in the protocol document.

q21.value: We will use the test implied by the power analysis as recorded in the protocol document.

q22.value: We will not exclude any data except for non-consent or partial responses and for the exclusion criterium of diagnosis of mental 'disorder' or direct acquaintance with people diagnosed with a mental 'disorder' as mentioned higher.

q24.value:
Within subject evolution of dependent variables.

Between subject differences of blame attribution/social distance & isolation of 'epigenetic' and 'label disclosure' steps. 

Correlation between demographics as collected and responses.

We also ask some open text feedback from participants which we won't disclose but that could inspire interpretation of data or tuning towards further studies.

attributes.title: Oral Microbiome Response to Powered vs Manual Toothbrush: Protocol for Systematic Review & Meta-Analysis
attributes.description: Subclinical changes in response to different types and generations of toothbrushes represent a challenging knowledge gap in the context of self-administered oral hygiene regimes. The aim of this project is to evaluate the current evidence regarding the microbiological changes and how they correlate with empirical findings namely the clinical parameters.

q1.value: Oral Microbiome Response to Powered vs Manual Toothbrush: Protocol for a Systematic Review & Meta-Analysis

q2.value: Abanoub Riad, Jitka Klugarova, Veronika Chuchmova, Simona Slezakova, Andrea Pokorna, Martin Krsek, Miloslav Klugar

q3.value:
This systematic review and meta-analysis will be the first to evaluate the oral microbial changes
in response to powered versus manual toothbrushing.

q4.value:
Subclinical changes in response to different types and generations of toothbrushes represent a challenging knowledge gap in the context of self-administered oral hygiene regimes.

This review is trying to answer the following questions:
1. Is there a significant difference between powered and manual toothbrushing in terms of oral microbiome response?
2. Are the microbiological changes significantly correlated with clinical changes in response to powered and manual toothbrushing?
3. If the answer of the 1st question is Yes; Which toothbrushing modality is more effective in reducing pathogenic microorganisms?
4. If the answer of the 1st question is Yes; What are the most sensitive oral species to powered toothbrushing and to manual toothbrushing?
5. If the answer of the 2nd question is Yes; What is the most diagnostic lab testing protocol that identifies microbiological changes in correlation to clinical changes?

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We will conduct a systematic review using the Cochrane Handbook’s guidelines and will adhere to a standardized reporting format: Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA). A comprehensive search strategy will be conducted in the following databases for published studies: Ovid MEDLINE(R), EMBASE, Cochrane Library, Web of Science, Scopus, ProQuest Central, ProQuest Dissertations Theses Global, Bibliographia medica Cechoslovaca and Dentistry Oral Sciences Source. Following a two-level screening process, data including the full reference, objectives, target population, description of the intervention and control intervention, outcome measures, design, length of post-intervention follow-up period, and the study results will be extracted, synthesized, and reported. Risk of bias and quality of the studies will also be assessed.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
An initial limited search of MEDLINE and EMBASE will be undertaken followed by the analysis of the text words contained in the title and abstract, and of the index terms used to describe article.
A second search using all identified keywords and index terms will then be undertaken across all included databases.
Thirdly, the reference list of all identified reports and articles will be searched for additional studies.
Studies published in all possible languages, if they have a title and an abstract in English will be considered for inclusion in this review. Studies published without any time restriction will also be considered for inclusion in this review.
The databases to be searched include:
Ovid MEDLINE(R), EMBASE, Cochrane Library, Web of Science, Scopus, ProQuest Central, ProQuest Dissertations & Theses Global, Bibliographia medica Čechoslovaca, Dentistry & Oral Sciences Source.
The search for unpublished studies will include:
Open Grey, Current Controlled Trials (ISRCTN registry), MedNar, ClinicalTrials.gov., International Clinical Trials Registry Platform of the World Health Organisation

q13.value:
This systematic review will be developed according to published guidelines18 and reported according to the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and Meta-analysis (PRISMA).  (Appendix 1)
Eligibility of papers for inclusion in the review will be assessed inclusion and exclusion criteria applied to each of the following domains: study designs, types of participants, types of interventions and comparison conditions, and the outcome measures assessed.

question.value:
The primary outcome measures employed to evaluate the effectiveness of powered versus manual toothbrushes in terms of oral microbiome will be included. Microbiological samples harvested from the following sites will be included:
a. sub-gingival plaque
b. supra-gingival plaque
c. oral rinse (salivary)
d. oral mucosa (buccal or labial)
e. tongue (dorsal or lateral)
All studies using molecular methods for identifying and quantifying oral microbiota species will be included.
The secondary outcome measures employed to evaluate the effectiveness of powered versus manual toothbrushes in terms of clinical parameters will be included.
The following periodontal indices used for evaluating oral health will be included:
a. Plaque Index (Quigley Hein Turesky, Silness and Loe, Visible Plaque Index Ainamo Bay, Ortho Modification of Silness andLoe, Navy Plaque Index mod Rustogi, and O’Leary Index)
b. Gingival Index (Loe Silness, Lobene Gingival Index, Bleeding on Probing, Papillary Bleeding Index, and Bleeding onMarginal Probing)
c. Periodontal Index (Rusell’s Periodontal Index, Community Periodontal Index of Treatment Needs)

q1.value: The relative prevalence of disordered engagement with social media, games, and other hobbies

q4.value:

H2: The proportion of frequent social media users who engage in this activity in a disordered way will be greater than the proportion of people who frequently socialise in person with friends who engage in that activity in a disordered way.

H18: Disordered engagement with social media will be linked to anxiety, even when self-criticality is taken into account

H26: Disordered engagement in reading novels will be linked to anxiety, even when self-criticality is taken into account

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We have a cross-sectional design

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: A nationally representative sample of 1200 individuals aged 18+ will be recruited via prolific.ac. This sample will be quota-sampled to be nationally representative according to the UK 2011 census along gender, sex, and race axes.

q13.value: we will sample up to n=1200, and then exclude individuals according to pre-specified exclusion rules.

question.value:
Engagement in a variety of activities will be measured by asking participants the following question: "Over the past 12 months, how often would you say that you have engaged in each of these behaviours?"

Responses will be measured on a 7-point scale: (1) Not at all; (2) Less than 10 times in total; (3) Once a month; (4) 2-3 times a month; (5) Once a week; (6) 2-3 times a week; (7) 4 or more times a week.

Engagement in the following activities will be measured: 
(1) using social media
(2) playing video games
(3) gambling
(4) taking part in exercise
(5) socialising with friends in person
(6) playing sports in person
(7) reading novels

Disordered engagement with social media, video games, gambling, exercise, socialising with friends, playing sports, and reading novels will then be measured using a similar procedure to the previous registration present in this OSF project: Separate scales that involve the scoring of 9 dichotomous items (Yes/No) and are based on the Internet Gaming Disorder Scale available at  http://dx.doi.org/10.1037/pas0000062

The specific composition of instruments measuring both absolute engagement and disordered engagement is attached as a file below named "Activity Engagement.docx".

Anxiety and depression will be measured via the GAD and PHQ. These are attached below as 'Outcomes.docx'

Self-criticality will be measured via the internalized self-criticism subscale of the Levels of Self Criticism scale. This is attached below as LOSC.docx.

H1-12 will be tested via a partially-overlapping z-test. This procedure is described in detail in  "Test statistics for comparing two proportions with partially overlapping samples"  (Derrick, Dobson-Mckittrick, Toher and White (2015)). This procedure is further documented at https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/Partiallyoverlapping/Partiallyoverlapping.pdf

The full procedure for these analyses is as follows:

1. We will calculate whether each participant engages frequently in each measured activity. The criterion for engaging in an activity frequently is answering that one engages in that activity at least once a month on the following 7-point scale: (1) Not at all; (2) Less than 10 times in total; (3) Once a month; (4) 2-3 times a month; (5) Once a week; (6) 2-3 times a week; (7) 4 or more times a week.

2. Disordered engagement in each activity will be calculated as a binary variable. This will be calculated by counting any individual who scores less than 5 on a measure of disordered engagement as non-disordered, and any individual who scores 5 or more as disordered.

3. The difference in proportion of disordered use within frequent users for each of the following pairs of variables will be tested: (1) social media vs. exercising; (2) social media vs. socialising in person; (3) social media vs. sports-playing; (4) social media vs. reading novels; (5) playing video games vs. exercising; (6) playing video games vs. socialising in person; (7) playing video games vs. sports-playing; (8) playing video games vs. reading novels.

For example: 1000 individuals in our sample might use social media frequently, and 100 (10%) of those might use it in a disordered way. 200 of our sample might read novels frequently, and 30 (15%) of those might read in a disordered way. Derrick et al's procedure would be used to see if there was a significant difference between the proportions outlined above within the partially-overlapping samples under test.

H13-26

To assess whether self-criticism explains the relationship between disordered hobby engagement and anxiety, we will undertake two separate linear regressions for each of the assessed hobbies (gambling, gaming, social media, reading, exercise, socialising, sports). First we employ a simple linear regression with disordered engagement score for each hobby as the independent variable, and GAD scores as the outcome variable. Next we will run a stepwise linear regression inputting self-criticism as a predictor at Step 1, disordered engagement score for that hobby at Step 2, and GAD scores as the outcome variable. The significance (p < .05) of the disordered usage term will be used to assess whether the effect of disordered engagement retains explanatory power after controlling for self-criticism. If the effect of disordered engagement on GAD scores is significant under the simple linear regression but non-significant under the stepwise linear regression, we will interpret this as evidence of full mediation. If the effect of disordered engagement remains significant in the stepwise linear regression, the R2 change score is significant and the effect size is smaller in the stepwise regression (c.f., the simple linear regression), this will be interpreted as evidence for partial mediation. If the effect of disordered engagement remains significant in the stepwise linear regression, the R2 change score is significant and the effect size is larger in the stepwise regression (c.f., the simple linear regression), this will be interpreted as evidence for a suppressing effect of self-criticism on the relationship between disordered engagement and anxiety. If the simple linear regression shows no significant relationship between disordered engagement and GAD scores, this will be interpreted as evidence that no relationship exists for disordered engagement with that hobby and anxiety.

To assess whether self-criticism explains the relationship between disordered hobby engagement and depression, we will undertake two separate linear regressions for each of the assessed hobbies (gambling, gaming, social media, reading, exercise, socialising, sports). First we employ a simple linear regression with disordered engagement score for each hobby as the independent variable, and PHQ scores as the outcome variable. Next we will run a stepwise linear regression inputting self-criticism as a predictor at Step 1, disordered engagement score for that hobby at Step 2, and PHQ scores as the outcome variable. The significance (p < .05) of the disordered usage term will be used to assess whether the effect of disordered engagement retains explanatory power after controlling for self-criticism. If the effect of disordered engagement on PHQ scores is significant under the simple linear regression but non-significant under the stepwise linear regression, we will interpret this as evidence of full mediation. If the effect of disordered engagement remains significant in the stepwise linear regression, the R2 change score is significant and the effect size is smaller in the stepwise regression (c.f., the simple linear regression), this will be interpreted as evidence for partial mediation. If the effect of disordered engagement remains significant in the stepwise linear regression, the R2 change score is significant and the effect size is larger in the stepwise regression (c.f., the simple linear regression), this will be interpreted as evidence for a suppressing effect of self-criticism on the relationship between disordered engagement and depression. f the simple linear regression shows no significant relationship between disordered engagement and GAD scores, this will be interpreted as evidence that no relationship exists for disordered engagement with that hobby and depression.

q20.value: Due to the potential for a non-normal distribution of scores, prior to undertaking the Linear Regressions outlined in our analysis plans we will inspect the scores on our each of the variables to be used in the regressions for non-normality. Specifically, we will examine the skewness and kurtosis scores. Where these scores are >2.0 in magnitude, we will undertake transformations on the variables. First we will attempt a square root transformation to normalise the scores. If this does not reduce the skewness and kurtosis scores to less than or equal to 2.0, then we will instead attempt a logarithmic transformation. For the logarithmic transformation, for scales including a 0 (e.g.,  use scores, 0-9), we will add one point to all of the data to convert the scale to a scale between 1-10 prior to undertaking the log transformation. In all cases we will examine whether our conclusions differ between the non-transformed and transformed scores. Where the direction of the relationship and significance of the relationship are unaffected and the magnitude of the effect is similar (+/- .05), we will report the untransformed analyses. If the significance, direction of the effect, or the magnitude deviates >.05 in effect size, then we will report the transformed scores in the main text. In both cases we will report the other analyses (if transformations were performed) in a supplementary analysis for completeness.

registration_responses.q12.question: A nationally representative sample of 1200 individuals aged 18+ will be recruited via prolific.ac. This sample will be quota-sampled to be nationally representative according to the UK 2011 census along gender, sex, and race axes.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Engagement in a variety of activities will be measured by asking participants the following question: "Over the past 12 months, how often would you say that you have engaged in each of these behaviours?"

Responses will be measured on a 7-point scale: (1) Not at all; (2) Less than 10 times in total; (3) Once a month; (4) 2-3 times a month; (5) Once a week; (6) 2-3 times a week; (7) 4 or more times a week.

Engagement in the following activities will be measured: 
(1) using social media
(2) playing video games
(3) gambling
(4) taking part in exercise
(5) socialising with friends in person
(6) playing sports in person
(7) reading novels

Disordered engagement with social media, video games, gambling, exercise, socialising with friends, playing sports, and reading novels will then be measured using a similar procedure to the previous registration present in this OSF project: Separate scales that involve the scoring of 9 dichotomous items (Yes/No) and are based on the Internet Gaming Disorder Scale available at  http://dx.doi.org/10.1037/pas0000062

The specific composition of instruments measuring both absolute engagement and disordered engagement is attached as a file below named "Activity Engagement.docx".

Anxiety and depression will be measured via the GAD and PHQ. These are attached below as 'Outcomes.docx'

Self-criticality will be measured via the internalized self-criticism subscale of the Levels of Self Criticism scale. This is attached below as LOSC.docx.
registration_responses.q19.question:
H1-12 will be tested via a partially-overlapping z-test. This procedure is described in detail in  "Test statistics for comparing two proportions with partially overlapping samples"  (Derrick, Dobson-Mckittrick, Toher and White (2015)). This procedure is further documented at https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/Partiallyoverlapping/Partiallyoverlapping.pdf

The full procedure for these analyses is as follows:

1. We will calculate whether each participant engages frequently in each measured activity. The criterion for engaging in an activity frequently is answering that one engages in that activity at least once a month on the following 7-point scale: (1) Not at all; (2) Less than 10 times in total; (3) Once a month; (4) 2-3 times a month; (5) Once a week; (6) 2-3 times a week; (7) 4 or more times a week.

2. Disordered engagement in each activity will be calculated as a binary variable. This will be calculated by counting any individual who scores less than 5 on a measure of disordered engagement as non-disordered, and any individual who scores 5 or more as disordered.

3. The difference in proportion of disordered use within frequent users for each of the following pairs of variables will be tested: (1) social media vs. exercising; (2) social media vs. socialising in person; (3) social media vs. sports-playing; (4) social media vs. reading novels; (5) playing video games vs. exercising; (6) playing video games vs. socialising in person; (7) playing video games vs. sports-playing; (8) playing video games vs. reading novels.

For example: 1000 individuals in our sample might use social media frequently, and 100 (10%) of those might use it in a disordered way. 200 of our sample might read novels frequently, and 30 (15%) of those might read in a disordered way. Derrick et al's procedure would be used to see if there was a significant difference between the proportions outlined above within the partially-overlapping samples under test.

If the effect of disordered engagement on GAD scores is significant under the simple linear regression but non-significant under the stepwise linear regression, we will interpret this as evidence of full mediation. attributes.title: The Effects of Toxic Behaviour In Games

q1.value: Who is exposed to toxic behaviour in games?

q4.value:
H1-4: Individuals who identify as non-white (Asian, Black, Mixed, Other) will be more severely exposed to (1) hate speech and threats of violence; (2) griefing; (3) unkind language; (4) gendered harassment than those who identify as white.

H5-8: Individuals whose gender differs from their sex assigned at birth will be more severely exposed to (1) hate speech and threats of violence; (2) griefing; (3) unkind language; (4) gendered harassment than those whose gender does not.

H9-12: Individuals whose sexual orientation is not heterosexual will be more severely exposed to (1) hate speech and threats of violence; (2) griefing; (3) unkind language; (4) gendered harassment than those whose sexual orientation is heterosexual.

H13-16: Individuals whose identify as a non-male gender will be more severely exposed to (1) hate speech and threats of violence; (2) griefing; (3) unkind language; (4) gendered harassment than those who identify as male.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We have a cross-sectional design

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: A representative sample of 1200 individuals will be recruited on prolific.co via quota-sampling groups based on the following criteria: sex, age, ethnicity.

q13.value: An initial sample of n=1200 will be collected. Exclusion procedures will then be followed (i.e. removal of non-serious individuals via prespecified rules)

question.value:
Gender will be measured by asking participants "What is your gender?" and giving them a free-text box to answer. For the purpose of data analysis, two coders will independently go through these responses and code them as (1) male; (2) female; (3) other. A degree of agreement of Cohen's Kappa > 0.9 will be used as criterion for reliability. Coders will be instructed to code obvious spelling errors and conceptual equivalences (e.g. 'Malr' -> 'Male'; 'Woman' -> 'Female') as the appropriate gender.

Sex assigned at birth will be measured by asking participants: "What sex was assigned to you at birth?" with the options: Male / Female

Ethnicity will be measured by asking participants: "How would you describe your ethnicity?" with 5 possible options: Asian, Black, Mixed, Other,  White.

Sexual orientation will be measured by asking participants: "Which of the following best describes your sexual orientation?", with the following possible options: Heterosexual (straight); Homosexual (gay); Bisexual; Other; Prefer not to say

"Hate speech and threats of violence", "griefing", "unkind language", and "gendered harassment" will be measured via the Exposure to Toxic Behaviour in Games scale (EXTOX), a 25-item scale that measures how frequently individuals have been exposed to a variety of kinds of toxic behaviour in games during the past month. Scores on items 1-6 are summed to form an index of "Hate speech and threats of violence"; scores on items 7-18 are summed to form an  index of "griefing"; scores on items 19-22 are summed to form an index of "unkind language"; scores on items 23-25 are summed to form an index of exposure to "gendered harassment". The complete instrument is attached below.

Hypotheses (H1-16) will be tested with a series of 16 separate Mann-Whitney U tests, with relevant demographic grouping as a binary quasi-independent variable and severity of the relevant form of exposure to toxic behaviour as a dependent variable.

More specifically:

H1-4: IV = Non-white (Asian, Black, Mixed, Other) vs (White); DVs:  (1) hate speech and threats of violence; (2) griefing; (3) unkind language; (4) gendered harassment than those who identify as white.

H5-8: IV: Gender differing from sex assigned at birth (SAAB) (Male saab-Female gender; Male saab-Other gender; Female saab-Male gender; Female saab; other gender) vs gender same as saab (Male saab-Male gender; Female saab-Female gender); DVs:  (1) hate speech and threats of violence; (2) griefing; (3) unkind language; (4) gendered harassment than those who identify as white.

H9-12: IV: Sexual orientation is not heterosexual (Homosexual; Bisexual; Other; Prefer not to say) vs Heterosexul. DVs:  (1) hate speech and threats of violence; (2) griefing; (3) unkind language; (4) gendered harassment than those who identify as white.

H13-16: IV: non-male gender (Female; Other) vs male gender (Male). DVs: (1) hate speech and threats of violence; (2) griefing; (3) unkind language; (4) gendered harassment.

Participants will be asked one screening question. This will ask them whether they have used a series of 4 video games over the past month. One video game will be invented for this study. Any participants who indicate that they have played this game will be removed from the sample.

3. Rise of Warriors (Invented)

Any individual who responds 'No' will be excluded from the sample.
